We SeeBiz PVT LTD Hiring!🔹 Job Title: Software Architect / Senior Backend Engineer (Inventory-Based POS Systems) 📍 Location: On-site/Lahore 💼 Department: Engineering / Technology 🕒 Job Type: Full-timePosition OverviewWe are looking for a highly experienced Software Architect / Engineer with a strong background in designing and scaling inventory-based POS systems. The ideal candidate is a technical leader with a hands-on approach to architecture, development, and deployment — someone who thrives in fast-paced environments and has experience across multiple stacks.Key ResponsibilitiesArchitect, design, and lead the development of robust inventory and POS systems.Define scalable and secure backend structures using Node.js, PHP (CodeIgniter, Laravel), and MEAN/MERN stacks.Work closely with product managers and UI/UX teams to turn requirements into technical solutions.Optimize databases using Amazon RDS (MySQL/PostgreSQL) for performance and scalability.Ensure CI/CD pipelines and DevOps processes are streamlined and maintained.Deploy, monitor, and troubleshoot applications on AWS (EC2, S3, Lambda, RDS, CloudWatch, etc.)Review code, mentor junior engineers, and enforce best practices.🔎 Required Skills & Experience10+ years of hands-on development experience in Inventory Management and POS SystemsExpertise in Node.js, Express.js, and RESTful API developmentStrong command over MEAN/MERN stackProficiency in PHP frameworks like CodeIgniter and LaravelSolid experience with MySQL/PostgreSQL, especially with Amazon RDSFamiliar with microservices architecture and scalable backend patternsExperience with AWS services (EC2, RDS, S3, Lambda, API Gateway)Strong DevOps knowledge — Docker, Git, CI/CD, Nginx, etc.Ability to write clean, testable, and maintainable code🔦 Soft Skills:Strong leadership and communication abilities.Ability to translate business requirements into scalable technical designs.Problem-solving mindset with attention to detail.Comfortable working in agile and cross-functional teams.👉🏻 Nice to HaveExperience with multi-tenant SaaS platformsExposure to Elasticsearch, Redis, or message queues (RabbitMQ/SQS)Prior leadership or team mentoring experienceFamiliarity with mobile app backends or integration with third-party services (Twilio, Stripe, etc.)💲 Perks & BenefitsCompetitive salary.Flexible working hours / Hybrid optionsPaid time off & health insuranceProfessional development opportunitiesWork with a global team on a mission-driven product📧 How to ApplySend your resume and portfolio/GitHub to careers@pk.see.biz with the subject: “Application – Software Architect / Sr Backend Engineer (POS Systems)”

One of the most powerful capabilities in Palette is its declarative management across the entire Kubernetes stack. While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. At the core of this approach is a robust implementation of the CNCF Cluster API. With Cluster Profiles, teams can define reusable and composable stacks that are continuously reconciled and self-healing throughout their lifecycle.This level of automation is a key reason why organizations choose Spectro Cloud. If you are interested in what makes Palette different, this page is a great place to begin: https://okt.to/DkCTYiWe believe this is the future of infrastructure automation, and we are just getting started. One of the most powerful capabilities in Palette is its declarative management across the entire Kubernetes stack. While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. At the core of this approach is a robust implementation of the CNCF Cluster API. With Cluster Profiles, teams can define reusable and composable stacks that are continuously reconciled and self-healing throughout their lifecycle.This level of automation is a key reason why organizations choose Spectro Cloud. If you are interested in what makes Palette different, this page is a great place to begin: https://okt.to/DkCTYiWe believe this is the future of infrastructure automation, and we are just getting started. Most of the lead scorings are broken. Here’s how to unbreak themLet’s be real: most lead scoring models feel like horoscopes dressed up in spreadsheets. "10+ job listings? Score: 70." "Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. I'll help you rebuild your scoring framework based on your purposes.hashtag#leadscoring hashtag#salesstrategy hashtag#b2bsaas hashtag#revops hashtag#demandgen

One of the most powerful capabilities in Palette is its declarative management across the entire Kubernetes stack. While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. At the core of this approach is a robust implementation of the CNCF Cluster API. With Cluster Profiles, teams can define reusable and composable stacks that are continuously reconciled and self-healing throughout their lifecycle.This level of automation is a key reason why organizations choose Spectro Cloud. Most of the lead scorings are broken. Here’s how to unbreak themLet’s be real: most lead scoring models feel like horoscopes dressed up in spreadsheets. "10+ job listings? Score: 70." "Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. I'll help you rebuild your scoring framework based on your purposes.hashtag#leadscoring hashtag#salesstrategy hashtag#b2bsaas hashtag#revops hashtag#demandgen

Most of the lead scorings are broken. Here’s how to unbreak themLet’s be real: most lead scoring models feel like horoscopes dressed up in spreadsheets. "10+ job listings? Score: 70." "Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. I'll help you rebuild your scoring framework based on your purposes.hashtag#leadscoring hashtag#salesstrategy hashtag#b2bsaas hashtag#revops hashtag#demandgen

One of the most powerful capabilities in Palette is its declarative management across the entire Kubernetes stack. While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. At the core of this approach is a robust implementation of the CNCF Cluster API. One of the most powerful capabilities in Palette is its declarative management across the entire Kubernetes stack. While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. At the core of this approach is a robust implementation of the CNCF Cluster API. With Cluster Profiles, teams can define reusable and composable stacks that are continuously reconciled and self-healing throughout their lifecycle.This level of automation is a key reason why organizations choose Spectro Cloud. Most of the lead scorings are broken. Here’s how to unbreak themLet’s be real: most lead scoring models feel like horoscopes dressed up in spreadsheets. "10+ job listings? Score: 70." "Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. I'll help you rebuild your scoring framework based on your purposes.hashtag#leadscoring hashtag#salesstrategy hashtag#b2bsaas hashtag#revops hashtag#demandgen

While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. Most of the lead scorings are broken. Here’s how to unbreak themLet’s be real: most lead scoring models feel like horoscopes dressed up in spreadsheets. "10+ job listings? Score: 70." "Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. I'll help you rebuild your scoring framework based on your purposes.hashtag#leadscoring hashtag#salesstrategy hashtag#b2bsaas hashtag#revops hashtag#demandgen

Ever wonder why some companies shortlist candidates, schedule interviews, even say “we’ll move forward”… and then completely go silent?In the past few months, I’ve seen a pattern — you go through one or two rounds (sometimes even three), the feedback seems positive, you're told they’ll be in touch for next steps... and then weeks pass by with no update.It’s tough — as candidates, we prepare hard, invest time, and remain hopeful, only to be left in the dark. Sometimes we never hear back, not even after two months.This isn’t about calling out anyone — it’s about raising awareness. A simple “yes” or “no” helps candidates move forward with clarity. Communication makes all the difference.To all the recruiters and hiring managers who do keep candidates informed: thank you — it truly means a lot.And to my fellow job seekers: stay strong, stay consistent. The right opportunity will come. 💪hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#TechInterviews hashtag#CandidateExperience hashtag#DevOps hashtag#HiringTransparency hashtag#AWS hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Terraform

While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. Most of the lead scorings are broken. Here’s how to unbreak themLet’s be real: most lead scoring models feel like horoscopes dressed up in spreadsheets. "10+ job listings? Score: 70." "Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. I'll help you rebuild your scoring framework based on your purposes.hashtag#leadscoring hashtag#salesstrategy hashtag#b2bsaas hashtag#revops hashtag#demandgen

Ever wonder why some companies shortlist candidates, schedule interviews, even say “we’ll move forward”… and then completely go silent?In the past few months, I’ve seen a pattern — you go through one or two rounds (sometimes even three), the feedback seems positive, you're told they’ll be in touch for next steps... and then weeks pass by with no update.It’s tough — as candidates, we prepare hard, invest time, and remain hopeful, only to be left in the dark. Sometimes we never hear back, not even after two months.This isn’t about calling out anyone — it’s about raising awareness. A simple “yes” or “no” helps candidates move forward with clarity. Communication makes all the difference.To all the recruiters and hiring managers who do keep candidates informed: thank you — it truly means a lot.And to my fellow job seekers: stay strong, stay consistent. The right opportunity will come. 💪hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#TechInterviews hashtag#CandidateExperience hashtag#DevOps hashtag#HiringTransparency hashtag#AWS hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Terraform

One of the most powerful capabilities in Palette is its declarative management across the entire Kubernetes stack. While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. At the core of this approach is a robust implementation of the CNCF Cluster API. With Cluster Profiles, teams can define reusable and composable stacks that are continuously reconciled and self-healing throughout their lifecycle.This level of automation is a key reason why organizations choose Spectro Cloud. Most of the lead scorings are broken. Here’s how to unbreak themLet’s be real: most lead scoring models feel like horoscopes dressed up in spreadsheets. "10+ job listings? Score: 70." "Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. I'll help you rebuild your scoring framework based on your purposes.hashtag#leadscoring hashtag#salesstrategy hashtag#b2bsaas hashtag#revops hashtag#demandgen

Ever wonder why some companies shortlist candidates, schedule interviews, even say “we’ll move forward”… and then completely go silent?In the past few months, I’ve seen a pattern — you go through one or two rounds (sometimes even three), the feedback seems positive, you're told they’ll be in touch for next steps... and then weeks pass by with no update.It’s tough — as candidates, we prepare hard, invest time, and remain hopeful, only to be left in the dark. Sometimes we never hear back, not even after two months.This isn’t about calling out anyone — it’s about raising awareness. A simple “yes” or “no” helps candidates move forward with clarity. Communication makes all the difference.To all the recruiters and hiring managers who do keep candidates informed: thank you — it truly means a lot.And to my fellow job seekers: stay strong, stay consistent. The right opportunity will come. 💪hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#TechInterviews hashtag#CandidateExperience hashtag#DevOps hashtag#HiringTransparency hashtag#AWS hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Terraform

"Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. Post Content:
Ever wonder why some companies shortlist candidates, schedule interviews, even say “we’ll move forward”… and then completely go silent?In the past few months, I’ve seen a pattern — you go through one or two rounds (sometimes even three), the feedback seems positive, you're told they’ll be in touch for next steps... and then weeks pass by with no update.It’s tough — as candidates, we prepare hard, invest time, and remain hopeful, only to be left in the dark. Sometimes we never hear back, not even after two months.This isn’t about calling out anyone — it’s about raising awareness. A simple “yes” or “no” helps candidates move forward with clarity. Communication makes all the difference.To all the recruiters and hiring managers who do keep candidates informed: thank you — it truly means a lot.And to my fellow job seekers: stay strong, stay consistent. The right opportunity will come. 💪hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#TechInterviews hashtag#CandidateExperience hashtag#DevOps hashtag#HiringTransparency hashtag#AWS hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Terraform

While many platforms focus only on initial infrastructure provisioning, Palette extends automation across all layers, from the operating system to integrations. Most of the lead scorings are broken. Here’s how to unbreak themLet’s be real: most lead scoring models feel like horoscopes dressed up in spreadsheets. "10+ job listings? Score: 70." "Marketing director viewed a whitepaper? Score: 40." "ICP match with a pulse? Score: 85."You know what all of that tells you? Nothing useful. Because scoring off firmographics and content clicks is like predicting rainfall from the color of the sky. You’re not wrong but you’re definitely not right either.The real buying signal isn’t who they are. It’s how they work.Here’s the shift:Don’t score accounts by titles. Score them by tension inside the team.That's what I'm talking about: 5+ vendor managers for a 20-person dev team 10 open engineering roles, but no in-house tech recruiter A CTO from Cognizant, and no DevOps hire in sight- These are buying signals hiding in plain sight.I threw out firmographic fluff and rebuilt a model that:- Flags structural gaps before job posts ever go live- Scores based on hiring logic and role distribution, not surface metrics- Tells sales why the account needs help, not just that they match ICPWho this is for:- GTM teams tired of chasing ghost MQLs- RevOps folks sick of scoring models that don’t reflect reality- Founders doing outbound and wondering why nothing sticksIf your lead scoring feels like a checkbox ritual, drop “score me” below. I'll help you rebuild your scoring framework based on your purposes.hashtag#leadscoring hashtag#salesstrategy hashtag#b2bsaas hashtag#revops hashtag#demandgen

Ever wonder why some companies shortlist candidates, schedule interviews, even say “we’ll move forward”… and then completely go silent?In the past few months, I’ve seen a pattern — you go through one or two rounds (sometimes even three), the feedback seems positive, you're told they’ll be in touch for next steps... and then weeks pass by with no update.It’s tough — as candidates, we prepare hard, invest time, and remain hopeful, only to be left in the dark. Sometimes we never hear back, not even after two months.This isn’t about calling out anyone — it’s about raising awareness. A simple “yes” or “no” helps candidates move forward with clarity. Communication makes all the difference.To all the recruiters and hiring managers who do keep candidates informed: thank you — it truly means a lot.And to my fellow job seekers: stay strong, stay consistent. The right opportunity will come. 💪hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#TechInterviews hashtag#CandidateExperience hashtag#DevOps hashtag#HiringTransparency hashtag#AWS hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Terraform
